text: Conscription Day is always the deadliest.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Maybe that's why the sunrise is especially beautiful this morning because I know it might be my last.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I tighten the straps of my heavy canvas rucksack and trudge up the wide staircase of the stone fortress I call home.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My chest heaves with exertion, my lungs burning by the time I reach the stone corridor leading to General Sorrengail's office.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This is what six months of intense physical training has given me the ability to barely climb six flights of stairs with a thirty-pound pack.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm so fucked.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: The thousands of twenty-year-olds waiting outside the gate to enter their chosen quadrant for service are the smartest and strongest in Navarre.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Hundreds of them have been preparing for the Riders Quadrant, the chance to become one of the elite, since birth.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I've had exactly six months.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The expressionless guards lining the wide hallway at the top of the landing avoid my eyes as I pass, but that's nothing new.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Besides, being ignored is the best possible scenario for me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Basgiath War College isn't known for being kind to.. well, anyone, even those of us whose mothers are in command.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Every Navarrian officer, whether they choose to be schooled as healers, scribes, infantry, or riders, is molded within these cruel walls over three years, honed into weapons to secure our mountainous borders from the violent invasion attempts of the kingdom of Poromiel and their gryphon riders.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The weak don't survive here, especially not in the Riders Quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The dragons make sure of that.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're sending her to die!
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: a familiar voice thunders through the general's thick wooden door, and I gasp.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: There's only one woman on the Continent foolish enough to raise her voice to the general, but she's supposed to be on the border with the Eastern Wing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: There's a muffled response from the office, and I reach for the door handle.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She doesn't stand a chance.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira shouts as I force the heavy door open and the weight of my pack shifts forward, nearly taking me down.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Shit.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: The general curses from behind her desk, and I grab onto the back of the crimson-upholstered couch to catch my balance.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Damn it, Mom, she can't even handle her rucksack.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira snaps, rushing to my side.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm fine!
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: My cheeks heat with mortification, and I force myself upright.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's been back for five minutes and is already trying to save me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Because you need saving, you fool.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: I don't want this.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I don't want any part of this Riders Quadrant shit.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's not like I have a death wish.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I would have been better off failing the admission test to Basgiath and going straight to the army with the majority of conscripts.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: But I can handle my rucksack, and I will handle myself.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Oh, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Worried brown eyes look down at me as strong hands brace my shoulders.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Hi, Mira.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: A smile tugs at the corners of my mouth.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She might be here to say her goodbyes, but I'm just glad to see my sister for the first time in years.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Her eyes soften, and her fingers flex on my shoulders like she might pull me into a hug, but she steps back and turns to stand at my side, facing our mother.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You can't do this.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: It's already done.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom shrugs, the lines of her fitted black uniform rising and falling with the motion.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I scoff.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: So much for the hope of a reprieve.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Not that I ever should have expected, or even hoped for, an ounce of mercy from a woman who's been made famous for her lack of it.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Then undo it.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira seethes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's spent her whole life training to become a scribe.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She wasn't raised to be a rider.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Well, she certainly isn't you, is she, Lieutenant Sorrengail?
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom braces her hands on the immaculate surface of her desk and leans in slightly as she stands, looking us over with narrowed, appraising eyes that mirror the dragons' carved into the furniture's massive legs.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I don't need the prohibited power of mind reading to know exactly what she sees.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: At twenty-six years old, Mira's a younger version of our mother.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's tall, with strong, powerful muscles toned from years of sparring and hundreds of hours spent on the back of her dragon.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Her skin practically glows with health, and her golden-brown hair is sheared short for combat in the same style as Mom's.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: But more than looks, she carries the same arrogance, the unwavering conviction that she belongs in the sky.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's a rider through and through.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's everything I'm not, and the disapproving shake of Mom's head says she agrees.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm too short.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Too frail.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What curves I do have should be muscle, and my traitorous body makes me embarrassingly vulnerable.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom walks toward us, her polished black boots gleaming in the mage lights that flicker from the sconces.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She picks up the end of my long braid, scoffs at the section just above my shoulders where the brown strands start to lose their warmth of color and slowly fade to a steely, metallic silver by the ends, and then drops it.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Pale skin, pale eyes, pale hair.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Her gaze siphons every ounce of my confidence down to the marrow in my bones.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's like that fever stole all your coloring along with your strength.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Grief flashes through her eyes and her brows furrow.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I told him not to keep you in that library.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: It's not the first time I've heard her curse the sickness that nearly killed her while she was pregnant with me or the library Dad made my second home once she'd been stationed here at Basgiath as an instructor and he as a scribe.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I love that library.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: I counter.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's been more than a year since his heart finally failed, and the Archives are still the only place that feels like home in this giant fortress, the only place where I still feel my father's presence.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Spoken like the daughter of a scribe.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom says quietly, and I see it-- the woman she was while Dad was alive.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Softer.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Kinder.. at least for her family.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I am the daughter of a scribe.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: My back screams at me, so I let my pack slip from my shoulders, guiding it to the floor, and take my first full breath since leaving my room.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom blinks, and that softer woman is gone, leaving only the general.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're the daughter of a rider, you are twenty years old, and today is Conscription Day.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: I let you finish your tutoring, but like I told you last spring, I will not watch one of my children enter the Scribe Quadrant, Violet.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Because scribes are so far beneath riders?
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: I grumble, knowing perfectly well that riders are the top of the social and military hierarchy.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It helps that their bonded dragons roast people for fun.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Yes!
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Her customary composure slips.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And if you dare walk into the tunnel toward the Scribe Quadrant today, I will rip you out by that ridiculous braid and put you on the parapet myself.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: My stomach turns over.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dad wouldn't want this!
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira argues, color flushing up her neck.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I loved your father, but he's dead.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom says, as if giving the weather report.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I doubt he wants much these days.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: I suck in a breath but keep my mouth shut.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Arguing will get me nowhere.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's never listened to a damned thing I've had to say before, and today is no different.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Sending Violet into the Riders Quadrant is tantamount to a death sentence.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Guess Mira isn't done arguing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira's never done arguing with Mom, and the frustrating thing about it is that Mom has always respected her for it.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Double standard for the win.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's not strong enough, Mom!
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She's already broken her arm this year, she sprains some joint every other week, and she's not tall enough to mount any dragon big enough to keep her alive in a battle.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Seriously, Mira?
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: What. The. Hell.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: My fingernails bite into my palms as I curl my hands into fists.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Knowing my chances of survival are minimal is one thing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Having my sister throw my inadequacies in my face is another.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Are you calling me weak?
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: No.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira squeezes my hand.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Just.. fragile.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: That's not any better.
speaker: Violet Sorrengail

text: Dragons don't bond fragile women.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They incinerate them.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: So she's.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: small.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom scans me up and down, taking in the generous fit of the cream belted tunic and pants I selected this morning for my potential execution.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I snort.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Are we just listing my faults now?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I never said it was a fault.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom turns to my sister.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira, Violet deals with more pain before lunch than you do in an entire week.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: If any of my children is capable of surviving the Riders Quadrant, it's her.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: My eyebrows rise.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: That sounded an awful lot like a compliment, but with Mom, I'm never quite sure.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: How many rider candidates die on Conscription Day, Mom?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Forty?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Fifty?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Are you that eager to bury another child?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira seethes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I cringe as the temperature in the room plummets, courtesy of Mom's storm-wielding signet power she channels through her dragon, Aimsir.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My chest tightens at the memory of my brother.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: No one has dared to mention Brennan or his dragon in the five years since they died fighting the Tyrrish rebellion in the south.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom tolerates me and respects Mira, but she loved Brennan.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dad did, too.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His chest pains started right after Brennan's death.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom's jaw tightens and her eyes threaten retribution as she glares at Mira.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My sister swallows but holds her own in the staring competition.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I start.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She didn't mean..
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Get. Out.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Out.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Lieutenant.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mom's words are soft puffs of steam in the frigid office.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Before I report you absent from your unit without leave.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Mira straightens her posture, nods once, and pivots with military precision, then strides for the door without another word, grabbing a small rucksack on the way out.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's the first time Mom and I have been alone in months.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Her eyes meet mine, and the temperature rises as she takes a deep breath.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You scored in the top quarter for speed and agility during the entrance exam.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: You'll do just fine.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: All Sorrengails do just fine.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: She skims the backs of her fingers down my cheek, barely grazing my skin.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: So much like your father,
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: she whispers before clearing her throat and backing up a few steps.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Guess there are no meritorious service awards for emotional availability.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I won't be able to acknowledge you for the next three years,
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: she says, sitting back on the edge of her desk.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Since, as commanding general of Basgiath, I'll be your far superior officer.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: I know.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's the least of my concerns, considering she barely acknowledges me now.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You won't get any special treatment just because you're my daughter, either.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: If anything, they'll come after you harder to make you prove yourself.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: She arches an eyebrow.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Well aware.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Good thing I've been training with Major Gillstead for the last several months since Mom made her decree.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She sighs and forces a smile.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Then I guess I'll see you in the valley at Threshing, candidate.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Though you'll be a cadet by sunset, I suppose.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: Or dead.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Neither of us says it.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Good luck, Candidate Sorrengail.
speaker: General Sorrengail

text: She moves back behind her desk, effectively dismissing me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Thank you, General.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I heft my pack onto my shoulders and walk out of her office.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A guard closes the door behind me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's batshit crazy,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira says from the center of the hallway, right between where two guards are positioned.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They'll tell her you said that.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Like they don't already know,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she grinds out through clenched teeth.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Let's go.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: We only have an hour before all candidates have to report, and I saw thousands waiting outside the gates when I flew over.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She starts walking, leading me down the stone staircase and through the hallways to my room.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Well, it was my room.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: In the thirty minutes I've been gone, all my personal items have been packed into crates that now sit stacked in the corner.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My stomach sinks to the hardwood floor.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She had my entire life boxed.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's fucking efficient, I'll give you that,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira mutters before turning my way, her gaze passing over me in open assessment.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I was hoping I'd be able to talk her out of it.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You were never meant for the Riders Quadrant.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: So you've mentioned.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I lift an eyebrow at her.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Repeatedly.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Sorry.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She winces, dropping to.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the ground and emptying her pack.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What are you doing?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What Brennan did for me?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she says softly, and grief lodges in my throat.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Can you use a sword?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I shake my head.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Too heavy.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm pretty quick with daggers, though.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Really damned quick.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Lightning quick.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What I lack in strength, I make up for in speed.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I figured.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Good.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Now, drop your pack and take off those horrible boots.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She sorts through the items she's brought, handing me new boots and a black uniform.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Put these on.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: What's wrong with my pack?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I ask but drop my rucksack anyway.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She immediately opens it, ripping out everything I'd carefully packed.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira! That took me all night!
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're carrying way too much, and your boots are a death trap.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You'll slip right off the parapet with those smooth soles.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I had a set of rubber- bottomed rider boots made for you just in case, and this, my dear Violet, is the worst case.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Books start flying, landing in the vicinity of the crate.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Hey, I can only take what I can carry, and I want those!
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I lunge for the next book before she has a chance to toss it, barely managing to save my favorite collection of dark fables.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Are you willing to die for it?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she asks, her eyes turning hard.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I can carry it!
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This is all wrong.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm supposed to be dedicating my life to books, not throwing them in the corner to lighten my rucksack.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: No.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You can't.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You're barely thrice the weight of the pack, the parapet is roughly eighteen inches wide, two hundred feet aboveground, and last time I looked, those were rain clouds moving in.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: They're not going to give you a rain delay just because the bridge might get a little slick, sis.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You'll fall.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You'll die.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Now, are you going to listen to me?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Or are you going to join the other dead candidates at tomorrow morning's roll call?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: There's no trace of my older sister in the rider before me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This woman is shrewd, cunning, and a touch cruel.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This is the woman who survived all three years with only one scar, the one her own dragon gave her during Threshing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Because that's all you'll be.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Another tombstone.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Another name scorched in stone.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Ditch the books.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Dad gave this one to me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I murmur, pressing the book against my chest.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Maybe it's childish, just a collection of stories that warn us against the lure of magic, and even demonize dragons, but it's all I have left.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She sighs.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Is it that old book of folklore about dark-wielding vermin and their wyvern?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Haven't you read it a thousand times already?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Probably more.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I admit.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And they're venin, not vermin.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dad and his allegories.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she says.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Just don't try to channel power without being a bonded rider and red-eyed monsters won't hide under your bed, waiting to snatch you away on their two-legged dragons to join their dark army.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She retrieves the last book I packed from the rucksack and hands it to me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Ditch the books.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Dad can't save you.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: He tried.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I tried.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Decide, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Are you going to die a scribe?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Or live as a rider?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I glance down at the books in my arms and make my choice.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're a pain in the ass.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I put the fables in the corner but keep the other tome in my hands as I face my sister.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A pain in the ass who is going to keep you alive.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: What's that one for?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she challenges.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Killing people.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I hand it back to her.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A slow smile spreads across her face.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Good.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You can keep that one.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Now, get changed while I sort out the rest of this mess.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: The bell rings high above us.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: We have forty-five minutes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I dress quickly, but everything feels like it belongs to someone else, though it's obviously tailored to my size.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My tunic is replaced by a tight- fitting black shirt that covers my arms, and my breezy pants are exchanged for leather ones that hug every curve.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Then she laces me into a vest-style corset over the shirt.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Keeps it from rubbing.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she explains.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Like the gear riders wear into battle.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Have to admit, the clothes are pretty badass, even if I feel like an imposter.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Gods, this is really happening.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Exactly, because that's what you're doing.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Going into battle.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: The combination of leather and a fabric I don't recognize covers me from collarbone to just below my waist, wrapping over my breasts and crossing up and over my shoulders.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I finger the hidden sheaths sewn diagonally along the rib cage.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: For your daggers.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I only have four.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I grab them from the pile on the floor.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You'll earn more.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I slide my weapons into the sheaths, as though my ribs themselves have become weapons.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The design is ingenious.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Between my ribs and the sheaths at my thighs, the blades are easily accessible.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I barely recognize myself in the mirror.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I look like a rider.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I still feel like a scribe.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Minutes later, half of what I packed is piled onto the crates.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She's repacked my rucksack, discarding anything deemed unnecessary and almost everything sentimental while word-vomiting advice about how to survive in the quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Then she surprises me by doing the most sentimental thing ever--telling me to sit between her knees so she can braid my hair into a crown.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's like I'm a kid again instead of a full-grown woman, but I do it.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What is this?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I test the material just above my heart, scratching it with my fingernail.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Something I designed,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she explains, tugging my braid painfully tight against my scalp.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I had it specially made for you with Teine's scales sewn in, so be careful with it.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Dragon scales?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I jerk my head back to look at her.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: How?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Teine is huge.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I happen to know a rider whose powers can make big things very small.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: A devious smile plays across her lips.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And smaller things.. much, much bigger.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I roll my eyes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira's always been more vocal about her men than I have been.. about all two of them.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I mean, how much bigger?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She laughs, then tugs on my braid.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Head forward.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You should have cut your hair.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She pulls the strands tight against my head and resumes weaving.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's a liability in sparring and in battle, not to mention being a giant target.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: No one else has hair that fades out to silver like this, and they'll already be aiming for you.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You know very well the natural pigment seems to gradually abandon it no matter the length.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My eyes are just as indecisive, a light hazel of varying blues and ambers that never seems to favor either actual color.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Besides, other than everyone else's concern for the shade, my hair is the only thing about me that's perfectly healthy.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Cutting it would feel like I'm punishing my body for finally doing something well, and it's not like I feel the need to hide who I am.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're not.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira yanks on my braid, pulling my head back, and our eyes lock.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're the smartest woman I know.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Don't forget that.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Your brain is your best weapon.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Outsmart them, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Do you hear me?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I nod, and she loosens her grip, then finishes the braid and pulls me to my feet as she continues to summarize years of knowledge into fifteen harried minutes, barely pausing to breathe.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Be observant.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Quiet is fine, but make sure you notice everything and everyone around you to your advantage.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You've read the Codex?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: A few times.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The rule book for the Riders Quadrant is a fraction of the length of the other divisions'.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Probably because riders have trouble obeying rules.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Good.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Then you know that the other riders can kill you at any time, and the cutthroat cadets will try.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Fewer cadets means better odds at Threshing.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: There are never enough dragons willing to bond, and anyone reckless enough to get themselves killed isn't worthy of a dragon anyway.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Except when sleeping.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's an executable offense to attack any cadet while sleeping.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Article Three..
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Yes, but that doesn't mean you're safe at night.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Sleep in this if you can.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She taps the stomach of my corset.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Rider black is supposed to be earned.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You sure I shouldn't wear my tunic today?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I skim my hands over the leather.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The wind up on the parapet will catch any spare cloth like a sail.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She hands me my now-much-lighter pack.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The tighter your clothes, the better off you are up there, and in the ring once you start sparring.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Wear the armor at all times.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Keep your daggers on you at all times.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She points to the sheaths down her thighs.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Someone's going to say I didn't earn them.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're a Sorrengail,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she responds, as if that's answer enough.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Fuck what they say.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: And you don't think the dragon scales are cheating?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: There's no such thing as cheating once you climb the turret.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: There's only survival and death.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: The bell chimes--only thirty minutes left.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She swallows.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's almost time.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Ready?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: No.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Neither was I.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: A wry smile lifts a corner of her mouth.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And I'd spent my life training for it.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I'm not going to die today.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I sling my pack over my shoulders and breathe a little easier than this morning.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's infinitely more manageable.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The halls of the central, administrative part of the fortress are eerily quiet as we wind our way down through various staircases, but the noise from outside grows louder the lower we descend.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Through the windows, I see thousands of candidates hugging their loved ones and saying their goodbyes on the grassy fields just beneath the main gate.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: From what I've witnessed every year, most families hold on to their candidates right up to the very last bell.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The four roads leading to the fortress are clogged with horses and wagons, especially where they converge in front of the college, but it's the empty ones at the edge of the fields that make me nauseous.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They're for the bodies.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Right before we round the last corner that will lead to the courtyard, Mira stops.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What is-- Oof.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She yanks me against her chest, hugging me tight in the relative privacy of the corridor.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I love you, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Remember everything I've told you.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Don't become another name on the death roll.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Her voice shakes, and I wrap my arms around her, squeezing tight.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'll be all right,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I promise.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She nods, her chin bumping against the top of my head.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I know.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Let's go.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: That's all she says before pulling away and walking into the crowded courtyard just inside the main gate to the fortress.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Instructors, commanders, and even our mother are gathered informally, waiting for the madness outside the walls to become the order within.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Out of all the doors in the war college, the main gate is the only one no cadet will enter today, since each quadrant has its own entrance and facilities.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Hell, the riders have their own citadel.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Pretentious, egotistical fucks.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I follow Mira, catching her with a few quick strides.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Find Dain Aetos,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira tells me as we cross through the courtyard, heading for the open gate.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dain?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I can't help but smile at the thought of seeing Dain again, and my heart rate jumps.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's been a year, and I've missed his soft brown eyes and the way he laughs, the way every part of his body joins in.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I've missed our friendship, and the moments I thought it might turn into more under the right circumstances.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I've missed the way he looks at me, like I'm someone worth noticing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I've just missed.. him.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I've only been out of the quadrant for three years, but from what I hear, he's doing well, and he'll keep you safe.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Don't smile like that,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira chides.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He'll be a second-year.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She shakes her finger at me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Don't mess around with second-years.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: If you want to get laid, and you should.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: --she lifts her brows..
speaker: NARRATOR

text: often, considering you never know what the day brings, then screw around in your own year.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Nothing is worse than cadets gossiping that you've slept your way to safety.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: So I'm free to take any of the first-years I want to bed,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I say with a little grin.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Just not the second- or third-years.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Exactly.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She winks.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: We cross through the gates, leaving the fortress, and join the organized chaos beyond.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Each of Navarre's six provinces has sent this year's share of candidates for.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: military service.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Some volunteer.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Some are sentenced as punishment.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Most are conscripted.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The only thing we have in common here at Basgiath is that we passed the entrance exam--both written and an agility test I still cannot believe I passed--which means at least we won't end up as fodder for the infantry on the front line.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The atmosphere is tense with anticipation as Mira leads me along the worn cobblestone path toward the southern turret.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The main college is built into the side of Basgiath Mountain, as if it was cleaved from a ridgeline of the peak itself.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The sprawling, formidable structure towers over the crowd of anxious, waiting candidates and their tearful families, with its stories-tall stone battlements--built to protect the high rise of the keep within--and defensive turrets at each of its corners, one of which houses the bells.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The majority of the crowd moves to line up at the base of the northern turret--the entrance to the Infantry Quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Some of the mass heads toward the gate behind us--the Healer Quadrant that consumes the southern end of the college.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Envy clenches my chest when I spot a few taking the central tunnel into the archives below the fortress to join the Scribe Quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The entrance to the Riders Quadrant is nothing more than a fortified door at the base of the tower, just like the infantry entrance to the north.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: But while the infantry candidates can walk straight into their ground-level quadrant, we rider candidates will climb.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira and I join the riders' line, waiting to sign in, and I make the mistake of glancing up.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: High above us, crossing the river-bottomed valley that divides the main college from the even higher, looming citadel of the Riders Quadrant on the southern ridgeline, is the parapet, the stone bridge that's about to separate rider candidates from the cadets over the next few hours.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I can't believe I'm about to cross that thing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And to think, I've been preparing for the scribe's written exam all these years.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My voice drips with sarcasm.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I should have been playing on a balance beam.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira ignores me as the line moves forward and candidates disappear through the door.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Don't let the wind sway your steps.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Two candidates ahead of us, a woman sobs as her partner rips her away from a young man, the couple breaking from the line, retreating in tears down the hillside toward the crowd of loved ones lining the roads.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: There are no other parents ahead of us, only a few dozen candidates moving toward the roll-keepers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Keep your eyes on the stones ahead of you and don't look down,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira says, the lines of her face tightening.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Arms out for balance.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: If the pack slips, drop it.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Better it falls than you.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I look behind us, where it seems hundreds have filed in within the span of minutes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Maybe I should let them go first,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I whisper as panic fists my heart.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What the hell am I doing?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: No,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira answers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The longer you wait on those steps--she motions toward the tower--the greater your fear has a chance to grow.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Cross the parapet before the terror owns you.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: The line moves, and the bell chimes again.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's eight o'clock.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Sure enough, the crowd of thousands behind us has separated fully into their chosen quadrants, all lined up to sign the roll and begin their service.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Focus,
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira snaps, and I whip my head forward.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This might sound harsh, but don't seek friendships in there, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Forge alliances.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: There are only two ahead of us now--a woman with a full pack, whose high cheekbones and oval face remind me of renderings of Amari, the queen of the gods.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Her dark brown hair is worn in several rows of short braids that just touch the equally dark skin of her neck.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The second is the muscular blond man with the woman crying over him.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's carrying an even bigger rucksack.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I look around the pair toward the roll-keeping desk, and my eyes widen.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Is he?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I whisper.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A separatist's kid?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Yep.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira glances and mutters a curse.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: See that shimmering mark that starts on the top of his wrist?
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: It's a relic from the rebellion.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I lift my eyebrows in surprise.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The only relics I've ever heard of are when a dragon uses magic to mark the skin of their bonded rider.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: But those relics are a symbol of honor and power and generally in the shape of the dragon who gifted them.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: These marks are swirls and slashes that feel more like a warning than a claiming.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A dragon did that?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I whisper.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She nods.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom says General Melgren's dragon did it to all of them when he executed their parents, but she wasn't exactly open to further discussion on the topic.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Nothing like punishing the kids to deter more parents from committing treason.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: It seems.. cruel, but the first rule of living at Basgiath is never question a dragon.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They tend to cremate anyone they find rude.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Most of the marked kids who carry rebellion relics are from Tyrrendor, of course, but there are a few whose parents turned traitor from the other provinces..
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: The blood drains from her face, and she grips the straps of my pack, turning me to face her.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I just remembered.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Her voice drops, and I lean in, my heart jumping at the urgency in her tone.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Stay the hell away from Xaden Riorson.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: The air rushes from my lungs.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: That name..
speaker: NARRATOR

text: That Xaden Riorson.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she confirms, fear lacing her gaze.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's a third-year, and he will kill you the second he finds out who you are.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: His father was the Great Betrayer.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He led the rebellion.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I say quietly.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What is Xaden doing here?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: All the children of the leaders were conscripted as punishment for their parents' crimes.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira whispers as we shuffle sideways, moving with the line.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mom told me they never expected Riorson to make it past the parapet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Then they figured a cadet would kill him, but once his dragon chose him..
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She shakes her head.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Well, there's nothing much that can be done then.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: He's risen to the rank of wingleader.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: That's bullshit.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I seethe.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's sworn allegiance to Navarre, but I don't think that will stop him where you're concerned.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Once you get across the parapet--because you will make it across--find Dain.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: He'll put you in his squad, and we'll just hope it's far from Riorson.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She grips my straps tighter.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Stay. Away. From. Him.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Noted.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I nod.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Next.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: a voice calls from behind the wooden table that bears the rolls of the Riders Quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The marked rider I don't know is seated next to a scribe I do, and Captain Fitzgibbons's silver eyebrows rise over his weathered face.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Violet Sorrengail?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I nod, picking up the quill and signing my name on the next empty line on the roll.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: But I thought you were meant for the Scribe Quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Captain Fitzgibbons says softly.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I envy his cream-colored tunic, unable to find the words.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: General Sorrengail chose otherwise.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira supplies.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Sadness fills the older man's eyes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Pity.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You had so much promise.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: By the gods.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the rider next to Captain Fitzgibbons says.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're Mira Sorrengail?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His jaw drops, and I can smell his hero worship from here.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I am.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She nods.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This is my sister, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She'll be a first-year.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: If she survives the parapet.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Someone behind me snickers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Wind just might blow her right off.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You fought at Strythmore.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the rider behind the desk says with awe.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They gave you the Order of the Talon for taking out that battery behind enemy lines.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The snickering stops.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: As I was saying.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: Mira puts a hand at the small of my back.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This is my sister, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: You know the way.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The Captain nods and points to the open door into the turret.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It looks ominously dark in there, and I fight the urge to run like hell.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I know the way.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: she assures him, leading me past the table so the snickering asshole behind me can sign the roll.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: We pause at the doorway and turn toward each other.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Don't die, Violet.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: I'd hate to be an only child.
speaker: Mira Sorrengail

text: She grins and walks away, sauntering past the line of gawking candidates as word spreads of exactly who she is and what she's done.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Tough to live up.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: to that,
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: the woman ahead of me says from just inside the tower.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It is,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I agree, gripping the straps of my rucksack and heading into the darkness.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My eyes adjust quickly to the dim light coming in through the equidistant windows along the curved staircase.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Sorrengail as in?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: the woman asks, looking over her shoulder as we begin to climb the hundreds of stairs that lead to our possible deaths.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Yep.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: There's no railing, so I keep my hand on the stone wall as we rise higher and higher.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The general?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the blond guy ahead of us asks.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The same one,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I answer, offering him a quick smile.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Anyone whose mother holds on that tight can't be that bad, right?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Wow. Nice leathers, too.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He smiles back.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Thanks. They're courtesy of my sister.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I wonder how many candidates have fallen off the edge of the steps and died before they even reach the parapet,
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: the woman says, glancing down the center of the staircase as we climb higher.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Two last year.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I tilt my head when she glances back.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Well, three if you count the girl one of the guys landed on.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The woman's brown eyes flare, but she turns back around and keeps climbing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: How many steps are there?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: she asks.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Two hundred and fifty,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I answer, and we climb in silence for another five minutes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Not too bad,
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: she says with a bright smile as we near the top and the line comes to a halt.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm Rhiannon Matthias, by the way.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Dylan,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the blond guy responds with an enthusiastic wave.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Violet.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I give them a tense smile of my own, blatantly ignoring Mira's earlier suggestion that I avoid friendships and only forge alliances.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I feel like I've been waiting my entire life for this day.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dylan shifts his pack on his back.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Can you believe we actually get to do this? It's a dream come true.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Right.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Naturally, every other candidate but me is excited to be here.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This is the only quadrant at Basgiath that doesn't accept conscripts--only volunteers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I can't fucking wait.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon's smile widens.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I mean, who wouldn't want to ride a dragon?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Not that it doesn't sound fun in theory.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It does.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It's just the abhorrent odds of surviving to graduation that sour my stomach.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Do your parents approve?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dylan asks.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Because my mom's been begging me to change my mind for months.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I keep telling her that I'll have better chances for advancement as a rider, but she wanted me to enter the Healer Quadrant.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mine always knew I wanted this, so they've been pretty supportive.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Besides, they have my twin to dote on.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Raegan's already living her dream, married and expecting a baby.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon glances back at me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What about you? Let me guess. With a name like Sorrengail, I bet you were the first to volunteer this year.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: I was more like volun-told.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My answer is far less enthusiastic than hers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Gotcha.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: And riders do get way better perks than other officers,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I say to Dylan as the line moves upward again.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The snickering candidate behind me catches up, sweating and red.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Look who isn't snickering now.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Better pay, more leniency with the uniform policy,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I continue.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: No one gives a shit what riders wear as long as it's black.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The only rules that apply to riders are the ones I've memorized from the Codex.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And the right to call yourself a supreme badass,
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon adds.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: That too,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I agree.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Pretty sure they issue you an ego with your flight leathers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Plus, I've heard that riders are allowed to marry sooner than the other quadrants,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dylan adds.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: True. Right after graduation.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: If we survive.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I think it has something to do with wanting to continue bloodlines.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Most successful riders are legacies.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Or because we tend to die sooner than the other quadrants,
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon muses.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm not dying,
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dylan says with way more confidence than I feel as he tugs a necklace from under his tunic to reveal a ring dangling from the chain.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: She said it would be bad luck to propose before I left, so we're waiting until graduation.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He kisses the ring and tucks the chain.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: back under his collar.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The next three years are going to be long ones, but they'll be worth it.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I keep my sigh to myself, though that might be the most romantic thing I've ever heard.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You might make it across the parapet.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: This one here is a breeze away from the bottom of the ravine.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the guy behind us sneers.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I roll my eyes.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Shut up and focus on yourself.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon snaps, her feet clicking against the stone as we climb.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The top comes into sight, the doorway full of muddled light.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira was right.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Those clouds are going to wreak havoc on us, and we have to be on the other side of the parapet before they do.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Another step, another tap of Rhiannon's feet.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Let me see your boots.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I say quietly so the jerk behind me can't hear.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Her brow puckers, and confusion fills her brown eyes, but she shows me the soles.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They're smooth, just like the ones I was wearing earlier.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My stomach sinks like a rock.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The line starts moving again, pausing when we're only a few feet from the opening.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What size are your feet?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I ask.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: What?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon blinks at me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Your feet. What size are they?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Eight.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: she answers, two lines forming between her brows.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm a seven.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: It will hurt like hell, but I want you to take my left boot. Trade with me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I say quickly.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I have a dagger in the right one.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm sorry?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: She looks at me like I've lost my mind, and maybe I have.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: These are rider boots. They'll grip the stone better.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Your toes will be scrunched and generally miserable, but at least you'll have a shot at not falling off if that rain hits.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Rhiannon glances toward the open door--and the darkening sky--then back to me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're willing to trade a boot?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Just until we get on the other side.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I look through the open door.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Three candidates are already walking across the parapet, their arms stretched out wide.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: But we have to be quick. It's almost our turn.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Rhiannon purses her lips in debate for a second, then agrees, and we swap left boots.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I barely finish lacing up before the line moves again, and the guy behind me shoves my lower back, sending me staggering onto the platform and into the open air.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Let's go. Some of us have things to do on the other side.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His voice grates on my last freaking nerve.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You are not worth the effort right now.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I mutter, gaining my balance as the wind whips at my skin, the midsummer morning thick with humidity.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Good call on the braid, Mira.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The top of the turret is bare, the crenelations of stone rising and falling along the circular structure at the height of my chest and doing nothing to obscure the view.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The ravine and its river below suddenly feel very, very far.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: How many wagons do they have waiting down there? Five? Six?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I know the stats.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The parapet claims roughly fifteen percent of the rider candidates.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Every trial in the quadrant--including this one--is designed to test a cadet's ability to ride.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: If someone can't manage to walk the windy length of the slim stone bridge, then they sure as hell can't keep their balance and fight on the back of a dragon.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And as for the death rate?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I guess every other rider thinks the risk is worth the glory--or has the arrogance to think they won't fall.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm not in either camp.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Nausea has me holding my stomach, and I breathe in through my nose and out through my mouth as I walk the edge behind Rhiannon and Dylan, my fingers skimming the stonework as we wind our way toward the parapet.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Three riders wait at the entrance, which is nothing more than a gaping hole in the wall of the turret.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: One with ripped-off sleeves records names as candidates step out onto the treacherous crossing.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Another, who's shaved all his hair with the exception of a strip down the top center, instructs Dylan as he moves into position, patting his chest like the ring hidden there will bring him luck.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I hope it does.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The third turns in my direction and my heart simply.. stops.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's tall, with windblown black hair and dark brows.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The line of his jaw is strong and covered by warm tawny skin and dark stubble, and when he folds his arms across his torso, the muscles in his chest and arms ripple, moving in a way that makes me swallow.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And his eyes..
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His eyes are the shade of gold-flecked onyx.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The contrast is startling, jaw-dropping even-- everything about him is.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His features are so harsh that they look carved, and yet they're astonishingly perfect, like an artist worked a lifetime sculpting him, and at least a year of that was spent on his mouth.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's the most exquisite man I've ever seen.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: And living in the war college means I've seen a lot of men.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Even the diagonal scar that bisects his left eyebrow and marks the top corner of his cheek only makes him hotter.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Flaming hot.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Scorching hot.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Gets-you-into-trouble-and-you-like-it level of hot.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Suddenly, I can't remember exactly why Mira told me not to fuck around outside my year group.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: See you two on the other side!
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Dylan says over his shoulder with an excited grin before stepping onto the parapet, his arms spread wide.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Ready for the next one, Riorson?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: the rider with the ripped sleeves says.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Xaden Riorson?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You ready for this, Sorrengail?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon asks, moving forward.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The black-haired rider snaps his gaze to mine, turning fully toward me, and my heart thunders for all the wrong reasons.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A rebellion relic, curving in dips and swirls, starts at his bare left wrist, then disappears under his black uniform to appear again at his collar, where it stretches and swirls up his neck, stopping at his jawline.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Oh shit.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I whisper, and his eyes narrow, as if he can hear me over the howl of wind that rips at my secured braid.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Sorrengail?
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: He steps toward me, and I look up.. and up.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Good gods, I don't even reach his collarbone.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's massive.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He has to be more than four inches over six feet tall.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I feel exactly what Mira called me--fragile--but I nod once, and the shining onyx of his eyes transforms to cold, unadulterated hatred.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I can almost taste the loathing wafting off him like a bitter cologne.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Violet?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon asks, moving forward.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're General Sorrengail's youngest.
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: His voice is deep and accusatory.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're Fen Riorson's son.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I counter, the certainty of this revelation settling in my bones.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I lift my chin and do my best to lock every muscle in my body so I don't start trembling.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He will kill you the second he finds out who you are.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira's words bounce around my skull, and fear knots in my throat.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's going to throw me over the edge.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He's going to pick me up and drop me right off this turret.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'm never going to get the chance to even walk the parapet.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I'll die being exactly what my mother's always danced around calling me--weak.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Xaden sucks in a deep breath, and the muscle in his jaw flexes once.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Twice.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Your mother captured my father and oversaw his execution.
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: Wait.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Like he has the only right to hatred here?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Rage races through my veins.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Your father killed my older brother.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Seems like we're even.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Hardly.
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: His glaring gaze strokes over me like he's memorizing every detail or looking for any weakness.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Your sister is a rider.
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: Guess that explains the leathers.
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: Guess so.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I hold his glare, as if winning this staring competition will gain me entrance to the quadrant instead of crossing the parapet behind him.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Either way, I'm getting across.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Mira isn't going to lose both her siblings.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His hands clench into fists, and he tenses.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I prepare for the strike.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He might throw me off this tower, but I won't make it easy for him.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You all right?
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon asks, her gaze jumping between Xaden and me.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He glances at her.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: You're friends?
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: We met on the stairs.
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: she says, squaring her shoulders.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He looks down, noting our mismatched shoes, and arches a brow.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His hands relax.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Interesting.
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: Are you going to kill me?
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I lift my!
speaker: NARRATOR

text: His gaze clashes with mine as the sky opens and rain falls in a deluge, soaking my hair, my leathers, and the stones around us in seconds.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: A scream rends the air, and Rhiannon and I both jerk our attention to the parapet just in time to see Dylan slip.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: I gasp, my heart jolting into my throat.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: He catches himself, hooking his arms over the stone bridge as his feet kick beneath him, scrambling for a purchase that isn't there.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Pull yourself up, Dylan!
speaker: Rhiannon Matthias

text: Rhiannon shouts.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Oh gods!
speaker: NARRATOR

text: My hand flies to cover my mouth, but he loses his grip on the water-slick stone and falls, disappearing from view.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: The wind and rain steal any sound his body might make in the valley below.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: They steal the sound of my muffled cry, too.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Xaden never takes his eyes from me, watching silently with a look I can't interpret as I bring my horrified gaze back to his.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Why would I waste my energy killing you when the parapet will do it for me?
speaker: Xaden Riorson

text: A wicked smile curves his lips.
speaker: NARRATOR

text: Your turn.
speaker: Xaden Riorson
